abstract.p: Outgoing Trinidad and Tobago prime minister, Basdeo Panday, criticizes election of political rival, Patrick Manning, as successor after parties tie in parliamentary vote; calls for new elections (S)

block.p: The departing prime minister, Basdeo Panday, criticized the recent selection of a political rival as his successor, insisting that new elections should be called instead. Mr. Panday's United National Congress tied with the opposition People's National Movement in the Dec. 10 parliamentary elections. President Arthur Robinson broke the deadlock on Monday by picking the opposition leader Patrick Manning for the prime minister's post. Mr. Robinson said he chose Mr. Manning by taking into account moral and ethical considerations, a reference to the opposition's campaign strategy of emphasizing accusations against the Panday government for sweetheart deals and corruption. Mr. Panday, however, accused Mr. Robinson of bias.
